column2: STUDIO PROBLEMS IN INTERIOR DESIGN I
column6: Studio problems in interior design is a course for the beginning student whose interest is in interior space design.
Studio based course introducing concepts of architectural drawing and sketching techniques including plan, elevation, section and perspective.

column2: STUDIO PROBLEMS IN INTERIOR DESIGN II
column6: Special problems dealing with design of residential and related spaces, traffic flow, placement of furnishings, emphasis on color and textural experience and lighting of space. Practical, integrated approach.
A concise background in textile science is estalishe3d with a hands-on approach to the evaluation, selection and application of textiles by interior design professionals and architects.
Relationships of well-being of individuals and families in the life cycle for a well-planned residence. Evaluation of housing, planning, financing and modern technological developments.
Chronological study of housing and furnishings from ancient civilizations to present, emphasizing cultural and social forces that contributed to evolution of various styles.
Studio based course continuation of ID 14512. Exploration of color, media and graphic representation of interior design materials and environments.

column2: STUDIO PROBLEMS IN INTERIOR DESIGN III
column6: Special problems concerning design of small to moderate size commercial interior space.

column2: STUDIO PROBLEMS IN INTERIOR DESIGN IV
column4: ARCH 10101 and ID 34503; and pre/corequisite PHY 13001.
column6: Introduction to large scale planning.
Practical and aesthetic study of interiors. Selection and arrangement of furnishings.

column2: COMPUTER AIDED DESIGN FOR INTERIOR DESIGNERS
column6: Introduction to application of computer drawing and drafting techniques used in interior design. Study of two dimensional and three dimensional techniques as well as symbol libraries.

column2: METHODS AND MATERIALS FOR INTERIOR DESIGN
column6: Information regarding the manufacture, construction and application of materials used in interior design. Proper methods and installation procedures of both surface materials and furnishings required in the profession are explored.

column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN INTERIOR DESIGN
column6: Workshops dealing with variable topics related to the interior design profession. Learning experiences provided in a broad spectrum of specialties.
Discussion of a major topic or issue within the profession of interior design. Repeat registration permitted.
Independent study of interior design and related topics under the guidance of a faculty member.

column2: STUDIO PROBLEMS IN INTERIOR DESIGN V
column6: Introduction to principles of historic design focusing on hands-on and on-site design techniques. For interior design majors only.

column2: STUDIO PROBLEMS IN INTERIOR DESIGN VI
column6: Special problems concerning the design of large-scale commercial environments.

column2: STUDIO PROBLEMS IN INTERIOR DESIGN VII
column6: This course will provide the opportunity for a senior design thesis. Problems will be selected by the students and will represent their own area of interest.

Designed to acclimate students to historic textiles created primarily for use in interior architecture. Focus is on aesthetics, design and construction. A comprehensive adaptive reuse or restoration project is required.
A study of the business and professional practices of interior designers.

column2: ANGLO-AMERICAN DOMESTIC INTERIORS, EARLY COLONIAL PERIOD
column6: An in-depth study of the Anglo-American interior and domestic furnishings with concentration on the preservation and contemporary usage of both interior architectural spaces and domestic objects.
Design application of lighting technology for various interior spaces. Field trips to study lighting installations.

Overview of historic lighting forms and techniques with an emphasis on Anglo-American design,18th to 20th centuries. Focus of course will be application of modern techniques to historic design problems.
A series of study tours for in-depth, first-hand experiences of historic sites, markets, manufacturing facilities and attendance at product seminars.

column4: ID 34504; and ARTH 22006 and ARTH 22007; or ARCH 10011 and ARCH 10012; and special approval.
column6: A chronological study of housing and furnishings from civilization to the 15th century.
A chronological study of housing and furnishings from the Renaissance to the Victorian Period-16th to 19th centuries and 20th century.

Practical experience in a furniture store, department store, design studio, architect's office or design-related agency directed by a qualified professional. Students' initial registration must be 4 hours not to exceed 10 credit hours. Repeatable for a total of 10 hours.

column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN INTERIOR DESIGN
column4: Interior design (ID) major and graduate standing.
column6: Workshop topics dealing with variable topics related to the interior design profession. Learning experiences are provided in a wide range of areas.

column4: Interior design (ID) major and graduate standing.
column6: Discussion of a major topic or issue within the profession of interior design. Repeat registration permitted.

column4: Interior design (ID) major and graduate standing.
column6: Independent study of interior design and related topics under the guidance of a faculty member.

column4: ID 44534 and ID 44535 and graduate standing.
column6: Designed to acclimate students to historic textiles created primarily for use in interior architecture. Focus is on aesthetics, design and construction. A comprehensive adaptive reuse or restoration project is required.
An in-depth study of the Anglo-American interior and domestic furnishings with concentration on the preservation and contemporary usage of both interior architectural spaces and domestic objects.

column4: Graduate standing and special approval and ID 34504; and ARTH 22006 and ARTH 22007; or ARCH 20001 and ARCH 20002.
column6: A chronological study of housing and furnishings from civilization to the 15th century.
A chronological study of housing and furnishings from the Renaissance to the Victorian Period, sixteenth to nineteenth centuries and twentieth century.
